citation.article-title: Ectothiorhodospira marismortui sp. nov., an obligately anaerobic moderately halophilic purple sulfur bacteria from a hypersaline sulfur spring on the shore of the Dead Sea.

p.s: Description of Ectothiorhodospira marismortui sp. nov.
Ectothiorhodospira marismortui (ma.ris.mor'tu.i. L.n. mare the sea; L.gen.n. maris of the sea; L.adj. mortuus dead; M.L.gen.n. marismortui of the Dead Sea)
Pleomorphic irregular short rods, often curved. 1.5-3.3 μm by 0.9-1.3 μm.
Multiplication by binary fission.
Motile by means of a polar tuft of flagella.
Gram-negative.
Intracytoplasmatic membranes arranged in stacks of lamellae (Fig. 2 B).
Color of liquid cultures red-purple.
In vivo absorption spectrum shows distinct maxima of bacteriochlorophyll a (591,796 and 856 nm, with a shoulder at 885 nm) and of carotenoids (486, 515 and 550 nm).

Photoautotrophic growth with sulfide or elemental sulfur as electron donor, or photoorganotrophic growth using acetate, succinate, fumarate, malate or pyruvate as carbon sources; poor substrates: lactate, glycerol, propionate, yeast extract.

Not utilized: methanol; ethanol; n-propanol; isopropanol; n-butanol; hydrogen; formate; butyrate; isobutyrate; citrate; benzoate; glycine; L-alanine, L-glutamate; glucose; fructose; mannitol; sorbitol.
Obligately anaerobic.
Ammonia or dinitrogen serve as nitrogen source.
Growth temperature 35- 45°C.
pH optimum 7- 8.
No growth factors required, but small concentrations of yeast extract stimulate growth.
Requires NaC1 (30-80 g/l optimally).
Accumulates glycine betaine, sucrose, and a third, still unidentified compound as osmotic solutes.
Lipid composition.
Four major polar lipid components: phosphatidylglycerol, and three still unidentified compounds.
Lacks cardiolipin and phosphatidylcholine.
Guanine plus cytosine content of DNA 65±2 mol% (thermal denaturation).
Habitat.
Microbial mats of hypersaline sulfur springs.
Type strain: EG-1, DSM number 4180 (German Collection of Microorganisms, Braunschweig, FRG).
